hero.title: Flowers of Beslan
hero.description: Twenty years ago, in the small city of Beslan, more than a thousand people gathered to celebrate the 1st of September — the start of the school year. Instead, they were taken hostage by terrorists and spent three scorching days cramped in a school gym without food or water. This act of terror took the lives of 334 people, 186 of them were children.

about.title: About The Project
about.author: Artist: Nina Lindell
about.description1: Flowers of Beslan is a handcrafted memorial that honors the 334 lives lost in the 2004 Beslan school tragedy through individually crafted paper poppies. Each delicate flower serves as a 'data portrait'. Its petals, height, and features are carefully designed to tell the story of one person — their fate during the attack, their age, their gender, and their connection to others.
about.description2: Created during one year of meticulous work, this project transforms statistics into a living field of remembrance, where every flower stands as both a personal tribute and part of a collective visualization of loss. The poppy field 'grows' in School No.1's assembly hall — now part of Beslan memorial center — where bullet-marked walls still bear witness to the events of September 1-3rd 2024.
about.description3: The installation is accompanied by an ambient soundscape: fainted music of Ossetian folk instrument Ӄisyn-Fændyr and the sounds of water, the water that the hostages so desperately needed.

section1.title: Idea
section1.description: The idea for this project came to me on September 1st, 2023, when everyone in Ossetia remembers the victims of the terrorist attack on School No. 1 in Beslan in 2004. The years pass, but the memory does not fade. On the contrary, each anniversary feels heavier than the last. I needed to find a way to process this – to make sense of it all. So I decided to create a handcrafted 'data-portrait' for each of the victims, something that would stand as an individual tribute while collectively creating a visual representation of the true scale of the lost lives.

images.caption: My concept image generated with DALL-E

section2.title: Inspiration
section2.description: The flower metaphor emerged naturally, as a usual attribute of commemoration. The Russian saying 'children are the flowers of life' made this metaphor even more fitting for the subject. I have also drawn inspiration from nature and children's books while reading to my son, as well as various 'data visualization' projects: a powerful memorial installation at the Tower of London and Valentina D'Efilippo's Poppy Field project.

images.caption: First World War commemorations at the Tower of London. Source: Historic Royal Palaces

section3.title: Data
section3.description:
I used data from PravdaBeslana.ru (a website documenting all factual materials related to the tragedy), which maintains a detailed list of hostages. Initially, I planned to create flowers for all 1,116 people trapped in the school. (According to other sources they were 1128). The flowers would be color-coded to show if a person survived, was injured, or died, while age and gender would be encoded in the flower's elements.

My concept involved grouping flowers of family members together to show that these weren't just individual hostages – they were families, friends, and colleagues. This piece of data was the most difficult to collect, and there were many unknowns until the last day.

I even considered including additional details to make the installation more personal: identifying teachers and highlighting the 24 women and babies released on September 2nd. This would have allowed viewers to trace stories like that of Aneta Gadieva, who faced an impossible choice between her daughters.

section4.title: Material Selection
section4.description: The possibilities for encoding depended heavily on the chosen material. Initially, I considered knitting or crocheting the flowers, as these were techniques I knew well. After creating initial prototypes, I realized this wasn't the right medium. The flowers were too time-consuming to create, and simply didn't have the tender and realistic look I envisioned. One December day at a Christmas market in Stockholm, I discovered crépe paper flowers made by Hanna Nyman (@backtopoetry). Their lifelike delicate beauty opened up a world of possibilities. And I dove into it, learned and experimented for a couple of months. My teacher and the master of paper flowers Sofia Vusir Jansson played an instrumental part on that journey, sharing her tips and tricks for bringing my technique to another level.

images.caption: Poppies made during Sofia Vusir Jansson's workshop

section5.title: Design System
section5.description:
Determining how to represent age and gender required careful consideration of encoding hierarchy. The most crucial information needed to be visible at first glance, while secondary details could reveal themselves upon closer inspection. That's why I reserved petal color – the most immediately noticeable element – to represent a person's fate.

For age representation, flower size seemed logical, but I needed to ensure smaller flowers for children wouldn't be overshadowed. My solution was to give smaller flowers taller stems, effectively using both size and height to highlight young lives.

To show gender, I experimented with various approaches: different flower types, rounded petals for women versus pointed for men, flowers with stamen for men versus flowers without stamen for women. Through testing, I arrived at a simpler solution: darker stamens for male flowers, lighter ones for female flowers.

section6.title: Crafting Process
section6.description:
The project gained real momentum in April 2024 after receiving encouraging feedback from the Mothers of Beslan Committee, an advocacy group of victims’ parents. Their support, combined with the possibility of installing the flowers in the school itself, gave me a clear purpose and deadline.

Creating each flower involved multiple steps: crafting stems and pistils, cutting out stamens and petals, shaping petals, and final assembly. I strived to make each flower unique by experimenting with techniques like coloring paper with ink and coffee, often achieving unexpected and beautiful results.

This project also connected other people to the tragedy of Beslan. My friends, people from different countries wanted to help and contributed to the process.

section7.title: Scope
section7.description:
Later in the process I realized that it was unrealistic to create and transport over a thousand flowers in such a short amount of time. So I changed the scope and focused instead on the deceased. This decision, while difficult, allowed me to give each flower the attention and care it deserved. 

The change in scope meant that I needed to consider not only the hostages, but also those who died fighting the terrorists and saving others: civilian rescuers, professional rescuers and members of Russian anti-terrorism special forces. 

This forced me to drastically experiment with coloring paper to find the right shades to represent these people.

images.caption: Unique and beautiful results: yellow paper colored with red ink, pink paper colored with blue ink, creme paper colored with black crepe paper

section8.title: Transportation
section8.description: The challenge of transporting over 300 delicate paper flowers from Stockholm to Beslan kept me awake at night. My solution was to pack the larger flowers disassembled and finish them in Ossetia. This gave me just 10 days to complete them, but thankfully my closest family and the Arts College students stepped in to help with the final assembly.

images.caption: Preparing for shipping: one third of the flowers on its way to Ossetia
All the flowers ready for installation

section9.title: Installation
section9.description:
Until the final day, uncertainty loomed over the exhibition. Would the flowers make the right impact in the vast 200-square-meter assembly hall? Would I be able to complete the installation myself and see it in real life? What should the color and material for the base be?

We received tremendous help from the Mothers of Beslan Committee and the Memorial staff who, despite a very tight deadline and no budget, worked wonders to provide the materials for the foundation.

Artist Emma Kelekhsayeva offered her wise guidance throughout the process. Just one day before my departure from Ossetia, we brought the installation to life. As a thunderstorm rolled in after a scorching day, Batraz Bitiev read out each victim's name, sharing stories of their families, while I planted flower after flower on the white field.

images.caption: August 24th. How will it all look like?
